Plains form as material from mountains settles and deposits along lower-lying landforms, creating gentle slopes and flat lands. The Kanto Plain is one of the major plains of Japan and offers a home to much human settlement and agriculture. In between individual mountains, valleys tend to take a V-shape. The archipelago of Japan contains over 4,000 islands stretching along the Pacific coast of East Asia, with four major islands (sometimes referred to as the Home Islands): Hokkaido, Honshu, Kyushu and Shikoku. The second largest, Hokkaido, is also the northernmost of Japan's islands; while on the other end, Kyushu is the most southwesterly. Shikoku is the smallest and least populous of the four main islands.

Japan has a dramatic landscape, with mountainous peaks in relative proximity to its lengthy shoreline. The island has the essential structure of multiple island arcs, each following the gentle curve of a tectonic plate boundary.
